update.description:
fixes issue #463 and [drcsim bug](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/issue/181/atlas-resets-to-origin-with-nan-poses-when)

(retargeting for default, will make a new pull request for 1.6 since this one has been tainted with default merge already)
update.title: fixes to treat fdir1 better.  1. rotate into link local frame.  2.  check if parallel to contact normal, if yes, revert to dPlaneSpace.

content.raw:
so far I use `qual_task_1.launch`, setting gravity to `(-1, 0, 0)`, when atlas foot comes into contact with any object with surface normal of `(+/-1, 0, 0)`, gazebo segfaults.
ticketed issue #630.
content.html: so far I use qual_task_1.launch, setting gravity to (-1, 0, 0), when atlas foot comes into contact with any object with surface normal of (+/-1, 0, 0), gazebo segfaults. ticketed issue #630.

content.raw: Actually adding them together seems like a bad idea too. If both surfaces have fdir1 directions specified, I think we should use the value specified by the surface with a smaller friction coefficient, since the friction properties of this surface will be dominant. If the friction coefficients are equal, print a gzwarn or gzlog message and do something arbitrary like averaging.
content.html: Actually adding them together seems like a bad idea too. If both surfaces have fdir1 directions specified, I think we should use the value specified by the surface with a smaller friction coefficient, since the friction properties of this surface will be dominant. If the friction coefficients are equal, print a gzwarn or gzlog message and do something arbitrary like averaging.

content.html:
EDIT: I've removed some lines from my suggestion. I don't like this averaging. I think they should be added together and normalized.

math::Vector3 fd = fd1 + fd2;
fd.Normalize();

content.raw:
This logic won't capture if fdir1 and the normal have opposite signs. I'll propose an alternate logical check:

On line 215, the variable t2 is computed as the cross product of fdir1 with the normal (since t1 is set to fdir1 just before). If fdir1 and the normal are close to parallel, then the length of t2 will be very small. I think a more robust check would be:
~~~
if (_dequal(t2[0], 0) &&
    _dequal(t2[1], 0) &&
    _dequal(t2[2], 0))
~~~
content.html:
This logic won't capture if fdir1 and the normal have opposite signs. I'll propose an alternate logical check:

On line 215, the variable t2 is computed as the cross product of fdir1 with the normal (since t1 is set to fdir1 just before). If fdir1 and the normal are close to parallel, then the length of t2 will be very small. I think a more robust check would be:

if (_dequal(t2[0], 0) &&
    _dequal(t2[1], 0) &&
    _dequal(t2[2], 0))
